text: Class II major histocompatibility ( class II ) genes are regulated in a B-cell - specific and <extra_id_0> gamma interferon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - inducible fashion .
The master switch for the expression of these genes is the <extra_id_0> class II transactivator <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

In this report , we demonstrate that one of the functions of <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is to recruit the <extra_id_0> CREB binding protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CBP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) to class II promoters .

text: Moreover , a dominant negative form of <extra_id_0> CBP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> decreased the activity of class II promoters and levels of class II determinants on the surface of cells .

Finally , the inhibition of class II gene expression by the glucocorticoid hormone could be attributed to the squelching of <extra_id_0> CBP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: We conclude that <extra_id_0> CBP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a histone acetyltransferase , plays an important role in the transcription of class II genes .
